name: Australian Shepherd
description: Australian Shepherds are intelligent, active herding dogs with moderate health risks. They're prone to eye problems, joint issues, and epilepsy. Their high energy also leads to more sports injuries. A good fit for active families who want a devoted companion.

faqs.question: What is the MDR1 gene mutation?
faqs.answer: Many Australian Shepherds carry a gene mutation making them sensitive to certain medications, including some sedatives and anti-parasitic drugs. Test your Aussie and inform your vet—it affects treatment options but not insurance coverage.

faqs.question: Is pet insurance worth it for an Australian Shepherd?
faqs.answer: Yes. Aussies are prone to hip dysplasia ($7,000+ for surgery), eye problems, and epilepsy. Their active lifestyle also means more accident risk. Insurance helps manage these costs.

faqs.question: Do Australian Shepherds have a lot of health problems?
faqs.answer: Aussies have moderate health concerns—better than many breeds but not problem-free. Main issues are joint problems, eye conditions, and epilepsy. Responsible breeding and early insurance help manage risks.

faqs.question: Should I get wellness coverage for my Aussie?
faqs.answer: Optional. Active Aussies may benefit from wellness plans covering routine care and annual eye exams. However, compare costs—paying out of pocket sometimes saves money.

faqs.question: Are sports injuries covered by insurance?
faqs.answer: Yes, most pet insurance covers accidents including sports injuries from agility, frisbee, or herding activities. Aussies are athletic and active, making accident coverage particularly valuable.
